section.hand:
To my L. T
re
r Sep
t
30 1591.

addressleaf.section:
1591 30 Sep
t
to my L. Trea
s

page.lettertext:
May it please yo
r
good L. since
e writing of my last
e 9
th
of this moneth, there hath nothing passed in this place in any
matter of consultation, or other forrene occurrence, that I could
think mighte de
s
ve to be reported to yo
r
L. As touching
Hulst
I did assure my self that her
Ma
t
ministers, w
ch
were
p
nt
at
e enterprise, would advertise sufficiently, & the winde
was Easterly; wherby there was meanes for theyr l
re
s to come
sooner to yo
r
L. then hether to
e Hage. Not onely
Zeland
w
ch
was moste of all annoyed by
e Land of Waes, but
e g
na
lity
of these countreys shall rx a great commodity by
e conquest of
t
place. The p
nt
somme wh
r
unto
e Country about Hulst, hath
yeelded for a monethly contribution is toward 800
li
st
r
ling, w
ch
after a while it is thought they may easely raise to triple as muche
moreover they have given hostages for
e paym
t
of 7000
li
ste
r
l
w
th
in
e space of a moneth to redeeme theyr countrey from
e spoile
of
e souldiers. In
e Towne it self of Hulst
e same order is
taken, for
e paym
t
of Impost & accise, & oth
r
publick taxes, as
they were put to before by order of
e Ennemy, w
ch
are greater unto
th
e
than are usually imposed upon the inhabitant
of these
countreys.
Count Maurice
hath concluded w
th
e
Councel of
state
to retourne again to
Niuemegen.
For by all adv
r
tisem
t
as
well from
e Countrey about it, as from some w
th
in
e Towne
theyr misery is such & so likely to encrease, as they cannot in
reason but yeeld ere be long. And besides wee have sent frind
w
th
in
e Towne in nomb
r
sufficient, when
e camp is come before yt
to make a faction w
th
in, w
ch
they do promise to do effectually
& assure us in a manner to be maisters of
e place. The
rendeyvous of
e states forces is assigned
e first of October
at
e fort of
Cnossembourg,
w
ch
is overagainst Nieumeg
e
. The
exploit it is thought wilbe quickly at an end, for w
ch
e Councel of
state doth not purpose to go hence. We are alwaies heer so ill
vided of intelligence of
e Ennemy, as we know no oth
r
c
r
tainty
of his going for
France,
th
e
e brute of
e people, w
ch
is
e
same
t
it hath bin that he goeth undoutedly. Nevertheles there
are many men heer of an oth
r
opinion, that he wanteth men &
mony to
s
ve his turne in both respect
, to give a royal assistance
to
e
D. de Maine
, & to defend himself at home. For now
t
he ys touched by
e
States
w
th
an offensive warre, his weaknes
is many waies very notably discovered, & espetially his ignorance
in
e stat e of those countreys, aswell in regard of
e strength of theyr
forces, as of
e nature & sute of theyr townes & places.
Heerof we are daily more assured, not onely by those cowrses w
ch
he hath taken all this sommer, but by divers l
re
s intercepted, &
chiefly nowe of late by certain neutrall
sons, men of very good
fol.220v
Belgia: 1591. Sep
t
jugement, w
ch
have conversed w
th
e chiefest of
e ennemies
& finde by all theyr discourses, that either God hath taken
theyr understanding from them, or they were never well enformed of
the state of thing
w
th
us. The
Em
o
rs
late intent
to
swade w
th
e states to treat about a peace is revived
againe. His Embassado
rs
meet in
Collen
e 5 of
e next
from whence they go toward
Brussels
& yf theyr purpose take
place from thence into
Holland.
Of this dessigne we und
r
stand by
divers mens letters, but by one in espetiall, w
ch
is newly sent
hether to
Mons
r
Sonsfelt
, a right honest gentlem
a
and an
antient
s
vant to Count Maurice from
Otto Henry de Billandt
Baron of Reide in
e Land of
cleave,
who is cousin to
e gentleman
& one of those embassadors. The substance of his l
re
ys to
swade
w
th
Mons
r
Sonsfelt being heer in good credyt, to make him self an
Instrument for
curing
e Count &
e states to hearken to a peace.
He promiseth great reward
& accesse of dignityes, to Count Maurice
by name, to
Barnevelt,
to
e
tie himself, & to as many of
e state
as are now in authority, & shall do theyr endevour to furder
e
treaty. Astouching matters of religion, he him self doth
fesse
to be wholy reformed, & in his owne jurisdiction to mainteyne
e same
religion, as is authorised heer in
e
United Provinces
. wheruppon hee
would infer that his meaning ys syncere. And if in those causes
the Emp
eror
&
e states should not come to a good agreement, that
then
e point
of difference shall be devided by certain Arbiters to
be chosen indifferently of
e Princes of
e Empire, & of bothe
religions. And for
e pollicy of theyr state, they shall enjoy theyr
antient rightes, immunities & privileges, in as ample & free
condition, as at any time heertofore. This is in effect
e
content
of his letter; wherw
th
Count Maurice acquainted me p
nt
ly
& im
ted it after to
e Councel of State. But theie needed nothing
to be sayd, for disswading any one to give eare to such treatyes.
For they were wonderfull carefull to suppresse
e letters
that no coppies might be taken; w
ch
was also an occasyon that I
could not as I would send a transcript to yo
r
L. Moreover
they delivered Mons
r
Sonsfelt
e argument of his answere to be made
as from himself: wherin he should declare, that neither
e chiefest
Governo
r
, nor
e commons of
e Countrey would either accept of theyr
embassade, nor give any audience or accesse to any that were sent,
or promise safety to theyr
sons, from
e outrage of
e people.
The rest that are named to be employed by
e enemy, besides
e
forenamed Baron, are not signified in his letters, but by other
advertisement
I learne that they are these. The
Seign
r
of
Barnsteyn
. The
Count of Lipp
.
Salentinus
of Issemburg,
[w
ch
was]
fol.221r
Belgia 1591. Sep
t
Bishop of Collen before Truxis.
Doctor Faber
, &
e brother of
e
Bishop of Witzburg. For mine owne
te I will use in this
matter all manner of vigilance, & as occasyon is presented
I will put yo
r
L. cautions in practise, w
ch
were sent mee
heertofore in w
ch
I purpose to proceed as to my understanding
shalbe most expedient for
e
s
vice of her Ma
ty
.
Sep
t
30 1591.
